title: 1610-A
statement: A. Anti Light's Cell Guessingtime limit per test1 secondmemory limit per test256 megabytesinputstandard inputoutputstandard outputYou are playing a game on a $$$n \\times m$$$ grid, in which the computer has selected some cell $$$(x, y)$$$ of the grid, and you have to determine which one.To do so, you will choose some $$$k$$$ and some $$$k$$$ cells $$$(x_1, y_1),\\, (x_2, y_2), \\ldots, (x_k, y_k)$$$, and give them to the computer. In response, you will get $$$k$$$ numbers $$$b_1,\\, b_2, \\ldots b_k$$$, where $$$b_i$$$ is the manhattan distance from $$$(x_i, y_i)$$$ to the hidden cell $$$(x, y)$$$ (so you know which distance corresponds to which of $$$k$$$ input cells).After receiving these $$$b_1,\\, b_2, \\ldots, b_k$$$, you have to be able to determine the hidden cell. What is the smallest $$$k$$$ for which is it possible to always guess the hidden cell correctly, no matter what cell computer chooses?As a reminder, the manhattan distance between cells $$$(a_1, b_1)$$$ and $$$(a_2, b_2)$$$ is equal to $$$|a_1-a_2|+|b_1-b_2|$$$.InputThe first line of the input contains a single integer $$$t$$$ ($$$1 \\le t \\le 10^4$$$) — the number of test cases. The description of test cases follows.The single line of each test case contains two integers $$$n$$$ and $$$m$$$ ($$$1 \\le n, m \\le 10^9$$$) — the number of rows and the number of columns in the grid.OutputFor each test case print a single integer — the minimum $$$k$$$ for that test case.ExampleInput2 2 3 3 1Output2 1NoteIn the first test case, the smallest such $$$k$$$ is $$$2$$$, for which you can choose, for example, cells $$$(1, 1)$$$ and $$$(2, 1)$$$.Note that you can't choose cells $$$(1, 1)$$$ and $$$(2, 3)$$$ for $$$k = 2$$$, as both cells $$$(1, 2)$$$ and $$$(2, 1)$$$ would give $$$b_1 = 1, b_2 = 2$$$, so we wouldn't be able to determine which cell is hidden if computer selects one of those.In the second test case, you should choose $$$k = 1$$$, for it you can choose cell $$$(3, 1)$$$ or $$$(1, 1)$$$.

processed.result:
You are playing a game on a $n \times m$ grid. A computer has secretly chosen a cell on the grid. You need to figure out which cell it is.

You can choose up to $k$ cells on the grid and ask the computer for the Manhattan distance between each of your chosen cells and the secret cell. The Manhattan distance between two cells $(x_1, y_1)$ and $(x_2, y_2)$ is  $|x_1 - x_2| + |y_1 - y_2|$.

The computer will give you $k$ numbers, one for each cell you chose.  

What is the smallest number of cells ($k$) you need to choose to be guaranteed to find the secret cell, no matter where the computer chooses it?

You need to find the minimum number of points you need to choose on a grid so that you can always determine a secret point the computer has chosen.  You can ask the computer for the distance between each of your chosen points and the secret point.
